body: Earmuffs were invented by a 15-year-old.
The smell of fresh cut grass comes from the chemicals plants release when in distress.
Nostrils take turns receiving the majority of the air you breathe, which explains why one is usually stuffier than the other.
When Arch West, the man credited with inventing Doritos, died in 2011 at the age of 97, his family decided to sprinkle Doritos in his grave.
When your "inner voice" speaks in your head, it triggers small muscle movements in your larynx.
Bubble gum is pink because that was the only food dye available in the factory where it was made.
Juicy Fruit gum, an early version of Cracker Jack, and the Ferris Wheel all made their debuts at the 1893 Chicago World’s Fair.
Army ants that misinterpret the scent trails left by other ants will sometimes break from the crowd and march in circles. If enough ants join, they can form massive "death spirals."
An estimated 1 million dogs in the U.S. have been named the beneficiary in their owners’ wills. (Humans are still in charge of the money, though.
Africa is the only continent with land in all four hemispheres.
Spike, the four-legged star of Old Yeller, was adopted from a California animal shelter—reportedly for just $3.
The Vatican Bank is the world’s only bank that allows ATM users perform transactions in Latin.
It’s illegal to own only one guinea pig in Switzerland. (They get lonely.)

Great white sharks rarely survive in captivity. Experts suspect the electricity in buildings interferes with the animals' electrosensory systems—though that hasn't stopped some aquariums from trying, and failing, to display them.
Abraham Lincoln had the opportunity to populate the United States with elephants. He turned the offer down.
In the 18th century, wealthy British landowners hired ornamental hermits to live in their gardens.

In 2010, Nickelback approached Dark Horse Brewery about having their beer featured in a video, which would have meant great exposure for the small Michigan brewery. They declined, however, as “none of us at the brewery really care for the band.”

Charles Richard Drew was a Black physician who developed blood banks for military personnel during WWII. He quit working for the Red Cross after learning that the military separated blood donations by race.
The NASA Vehicle Assembly Building in Florida is so huge it has its own weather.
The word dude originated in the 1800s as an insult to men overly concerned with the latest fashion trends.
Giraffes have the highest blood pressure of any mammal, although their resting heart rate is about the same as humans.
Theodore Roosevelt's daughter Alice had a pet snake named Emily Spinach. She liked to carry it around the White House in her purse and take it out at unexpected moments.
According to a 2015 study, less than half the world's cultures kiss romantically.
Sloths can move three times faster in water than they can on land.
Blood makes up about 8 percent of your total body weight.
Each year, 40,000 tons of space dust settles on the Earth.
Fireworks were ignited over Philadelphia to celebrate the first anniversary of the signing of the Declaration of Independence in 1777.
The Square Dance is the official state dance (or folk dance) of 24 states.
Opossums don't "play dead." When frightened, they become overexcited and pass out.
Ornithologists often use Cheetos to study behavior in crows. Along with being easy to spot because of their bright orange color, they’re also one of a crow’s favorite treats.
The heads on Easter Island have bodies.
Albert Einstein turned down the presidency of Israel.
The sound of the roaring lion over the MGM logo is actually a tiger.

For decades, artist Al Hirschfeld hid the name of his daughter Nina in his drawings for The New York Times and elsewhere. He'd add the number of times her name appeared to his signature, creating a game for readers, who would try and find each appearance.
Christopher Walken worked as a lion tamer in his youth.
Sometimes it snows on Mars—but the snowflakes are made out of carbon dioxide, not water. The flakes don’t fall, but create a fog-like effect.
The Palais Idéal in France is built entirely of stones a postman named Ferdinand Cheval picked up on his mail route.
As part of David Hasselhoff's divorce settlement, he kept possession of the nickname "Hoff" and the catchphrase "Don't Hassle the Hoff."
Jim Henson made his first Kermit puppet using his mother's old coat and two halves of a ping pong ball.
Big cats like lions and jaguars love catnip, too.
Hay-on-Wye in Wales is the used book capital of the world. It’s home to the famous Honesty Bookshop: an outdoor book market with a collection box in place of a cashier.
Theodore Roosevelt had a pet bear named Jonathan Edwards.
F. Scott Fitzgerald's full name is Francis Scott Key Fitzgerald. He was named after his distant relative Francis Scott Key, who wrote the words to "The Star-Spangled Banner."
J.K. Rowling invented Quidditch in a pub.
A newborn blue whale gains about 200 pounds a day during its first year.
When it comes to wine, an aroma similar to cat pee is a considered a good thing.
Blood donors in Sweden receive a thank you text when their blood is used.
Andrew Jackson's parrot was kicked out of his funeral for swearing.
The dust storms on Mars are huge: One 2018 "planet-encircling" event was the size of North America and Russia combined.
When he’s not busy predicting the weather at Gobbler’s Knob, Punxsutawney Phil—America’s most famous groundhog—lives in the town library with his wife, Phyllis.
Louis Braille was 12 years old when he began transforming a method of silent communication used by the French military into a language that allows blind people to read.
George Washington had only one tooth remaining in his mouth when he was sworn in as president in 1789.
The temperature at the polar ice caps—which are cold, arid deserts similar to Antarctica—can reach frigid temperatures of −189.67 degrees Fahrenheit.
Those tiny "seeds" on the outside of a strawberry aren't seeds--those are actually little tiny fruits!
The Spangler Candy Company chose to name their famous lollipops “Dum Dums” because it was a word that was easy for any kid to say.
Barbie's full name is Barbara Millicent Roberts.
Obituary writers have their own awards. They're called The Grimmys.
Wisconsin is known as the Badger State because the area’s lead miners used to spend winters in tunnels burrowed into hills. Like badgers.
Women in traditional Rwandan societies avoid eating goat meat as it’s believed it will cause them to grow a beard.
Lobsters' bladders are in their heads.
A British man changed his name to Tim Pppppppppprice to make it harder for telemarketers to pronounce.
In the 1880s, a baboon worked as a signalman for nine years on a South African railroad. He was paid in brandy and never made a mistake.
Blue whales have an average penis length of 98 inches.
Maya Angelou was San Francisco’s first Black female streetcar conductor.
According to 19th-century Welsh tradition, any infant whose nails are cut before the age of six months will become a thief.
The odds of giving birth to a baby at 12:01 a.m. on January 1 are around 1 in 526,000—roughly the same as the odds of getting struck by lightning.

In 2007, the end of Daylight Saving Time jumped from the last Sunday in October to the first Sunday in November. The decision was reportedly influenced by candy lobbyists pushing to get trick-or-treaters an extra hour of daylight.
Each spacecraft is scrubbed and inspected before it’s sent to Mars as part of a strict planetary protection protocol meant to prevent contamination from Earth.
America voted for independence from Britain on July 3, 1776. The text of the declaration wasn’t approved until July 4.
Geckos can turn the stickiness of their feet on and off at will.
Before he sang lead vocals for Black Sabbath, Ozzy Osbourne worked in a slaughterhouse.
A newborn giant panda is about the size of a stick of butter.

There are approximately 200 feral cats roaming the grounds of Disneyland, where they help control the park’s rodent population. They’re all spayed or neutered, and the park’s staff provides them with both extra food and medical care.
A face with big eyes, a small nose, and a small chin exhibits kinderschema: the collection of traits humans have evolved to find adorable.
The Crooked Forest in Poland is home to hundreds of pine trees curved at a 90° angle.
When pirate Richard Worley, captain of the New York’s Revenge, captured his second ship, he named it the New York Revenge’s Revenge.

In Scotland, the first person to cross your home’s threshold on New Year’s Day is expected to bring an assortment of symbolic gifts with them, which might include a coin, salt, bread, coal, fruitcake, or whisky. The guest, known as the “first-foot,” is then lavished with food and drink. One common tradition dictates that a tall, dark-haired man is the preferred first-foot.
In early drafts of the Back to the Future script, the time machine was built out of an old refrigerator.
In 1953, Swanson had 260 tons of frozen turkey leftover after Thanksgiving, so they packaged them into trays with peas and potatoes, and the TV Dinner was born.
Bangladesh has six seasons: Grishmo (summer), Borsha (rainy), Shorot (fall), Hemanta (cool), Sheet (winter), and Boshanto (spring).
Jeannette Rankin became the first female member of Congress in 1916, four years before the 19th Amendment was ratified.
The ancestor of the modern chainsaw was invented to facilitate childbirth.
Jim Carrey was the first actor to have three number one movies in one year.
Newborn elephants suck their trunks for comfort.
Eggplants are berries.
As comedian Bob Hope lay on his deathbed in 2003, his wife Dolores asked where he’d like to be buried. His reply: “Surprise me.”

The first Hershey’s chocolate bars with almonds were produced in 1908 because they were cheap to make. The nuts took the place of some of the more expensive milk chocolate, which meant Hershey’s could keep the price of the candy at a nickel.
On August 10, 1984, Red Dawn became the first movie to be released with a PG-13 rating.
The Woolsey Hall auditorium at Yale contains an extra-wide seat built to fit alumnus and former professor William Howard Taft.
Londoners in the 1600s were advised to keep "fart jars"—consisting of trapped fart odors—on hand to combat bubonic plague. The idea was that the potent smell would somehow purify the air.
A Canadian police officer named Ward Clapham created a program that gives “positive tickets” to people who do good deeds.
Ben and Jerry originally wanted to start a bagel company. The partners ended up in the ice cream business because they couldn’t afford a bagel machine.

The Antikythera mechanism, discovered by sponge divers in 1900, is sometimes called the world's first analog computer. Designed to calculate dates and predict astronomical phenomena, it was so advanced nothing surpassed it for almost 1500 years.

The dragon tree of the Canary Islands is famous for its thick, deep-red sap. Called dragon's blood, the resin might be responsible for the intense hue of the famous Stradivarius violins built in the 17th and 18th centuries.
According to a poll of 11,000 Americans, 84 percent of vegetarians and vegans return to eating meat.
Before he wrote Goosebumps, R.L. Stine wrote the jokes for Bazooka Joe gum wrappers.
Modern brunch was first proposed in 1895 as a post-hangover meal.
The office cubicle was invented by Robert Propst in 1968. His original design was called the Action Office System and provided “a social kind of privacy” for the worker.
In the late 1800s, residents of Corinne, Utah could buy divorce papers from a vending machine for $2.50.
China owns all of the pandas in the world. They rent them out for about $1 million a year.
Casting for Quentin Tarantino’s 'Jackie Brown' was partly done by Jaki Brown, and Lee Daniel’s 'The Butler' was cast by Leah Daniels-Butler.

As astronauts spend months traveling to Mars, their eyeballs may change shape. Some scientists believe that’s due to the pressure from fluids that won’t drain from their heads thanks to the low-gravity environment.
When Facebook introduced the News Feed in 2006, people freaked out. TIME called it “Gen Y’s first official revolution.”
In 1991, Wayne Allwine—who was then the voice of Mickey Mouse—married Russi Taylor, the voice of Minnie.
According to a Japanese study, looking at cute animal pictures can boost your focus.
Mars’s surface shifts in a different way than Earth’s, resulting in huge Martian volcanoes up to 100 times bigger than those on our planet.
Thumbs have their own pulse.
Some female sharks store sperm after mating, potentially holding on to it for years before they’re ready to reproduce.
During his inauguration, Teddy Roosevelt wore a ring that contained a lock of Abraham Lincoln's hair, which may be the 14th weirdest thing about him.
A double rainbow occurs when sunlight is reflected twice inside a raindrop. If you look closely, you can see that the colors of the secondary rainbow appear in reverse order.
Ada Lovelace, the daughter of poet Lord Byron, wrote the first algorithm created specifically for a machine.
Blood donors in Sweden receive a thank you text when their blood is used.
All newspapers in the British Library were ironed by hand to ensure a clear image before they were microfilmed.
Citizens of the Soviet Union began celebrating the defeat of Germany in World War II as soon as it was announced. Less than 24 hours later, the entire country was out of vodka.
A group of ferrets is called a business.
In Japan, instead of a "Man in the Moon," people see a "Rabbit in the Moon."
The Easter Island “heads” have bodies.
Jerry Springer was born in a London tube station during World War II.
Johnny Cash’s “A Boy Named Sue” was penned by beloved children’s author Shel Silverstein.
Nobel Prize winner Niels Bohr was given a perpetual supply of beer piped into his house.
Female bats give birth while hanging upside down, catching the baby in their wings as it drops.
During WWI, German measles were called "liberty measles" and dachshunds became "liberty hounds."

Mark Twain was born in 1835, a year in which Halley’s comet was visible from Earth. In 1909, he said, “I came in with Halley’s comet…and I expect to go out with it.” When he died on April 21, 1910, the comet was again visible in the night sky.
Ravens in captivity can learn to talk better than parrots.
On Mars, no resource can be wasted—not even bodily fluids. Urine will be recycled into drinking water and feces into fertilizer.
The dot over your lowercase “i” is called a tittle.
The Vatican's bank is the only one in existence that allows ATM users to perform transactions in Latin.
The world’s oldest surviving piano is at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York City. The instrument dates back to 1720, and was made by an Italian man named Bartolomeo Cristofori.
Floccinaucinihilipilification—one of the longest words in the English language—is the act of estimating that something is worthless.
Like casinos, shopping malls are intentionally designed to disorient visitors. The feeling of losing track of time and geography inside a mall is called the Gruen Transfer.
Jane Austen didn't publish her first novel under her real name. Instead, Sense and Sensibility was credited as being written "By a Lady."

A cat’s ability to see well at night is due to its tapetum lucidum, a structure that reflects visible light back through the cat’s retina. It’s also what causes the eyes' weird ‘glowing’ effect in the dark.
Tsundoku is the act of acquiring books or other reading materials and not reading them.
In 1916, Adeline and Augusta Van Buren became the first women to travel across the country on two solo motorcycles. They made it despite frequently being arrested for wearing pants.
LEGO is an abbreviation of the Danish phrase leg godt which means “play well.” The company was originally called Billund Maskinsnedkeri.

In 19th-century Ireland, jack-o'-lanterns were carved out 
of turnips instead of pumpkins.
North Korea’s 105-story Ryugyong Hotel, nicknamed "The Hotel of Doom," is the world’s tallest unoccupied building.
In a study by the Smell and Taste Treatment Research Foundation, the scent women found most arousing was Good & Plenty candy mixed with cucumber.
Nicknamed "sea bunnies," Jorunna parva is actually a highly toxic species of sea slug.
Octopuses don’t have tentacles; they have arms. A tentacle only has suckers at its end, while a cephalopod arm has suckers for most of its length.
St. Patrick wasn't Irish: He was born to Roman parents in either Scotland, England, or Wales.
The Hass avocado was patented in 1935 by Rudolph Hass, a mailman from California.
Goosebumps are actually caused by a muscle. It is called the arrector pili muscle.
The towns of Baarle straddle the Dutch-Belgian border. In some places, the official border line cuts through houses and cafes.
Tsutomu Yamaguchi was in Hiroshima for work when the first A-bomb hit, made it home to Nagasaki for the second, and lived to be 93.
Fire rainbows occur when the ice crystals in a cirrus cloud refract the sun's rays, creating a multi-colored cloud effect.
Frank Sinatra was offered the lead role in Die Hard.
Farm-raised ostriches get turned on by humans.
Wisdom teeth serve no purpose. They’re left over from hundreds of thousands of years ago. As early humans’ brains grew bigger, it reduced space in the mouth, crowding out this third set of molars.
Double Stuf Oreos are only 1.86 times as "stuf’ed" as classic Oreos.
LEGO has an underground vault with every set ever made.
Your hair contains traces of gold.
The German version of the term “Average Joe” is Otto Normalverbraucher, which translates to “Otto normal consumer.”
Wombat poop is cube-shaped.
Salvador Dalí designed the Chupa Chups logo.
Cleopatra had a special lipstick made for her, consisting of a crushed mixture of ants and deep red carmine beetles.
In the 1920s and ‘30s, many movie theaters had signs instructing ladies to "Please Remove Your Hats” to keep their elaborate headwear from blocking anyone's view.
Cicadas have been known to confuse the roar of power tools for mating calls and sometimes swarm people using lawn mowers.
People walked differently in medieval times. They stepped with the ball of the foot first to check the ground for debris, perhaps because well-soled shoes were hard to come by.
Toblerone is a portmanteau of the candy’s inventor, Theodor Tobler, and torrone, a word for various Italian nougats.
Long before rap battles, there was "flyting": the exchange of witty, insulting verses. The verbal throwdowns were popular in England and Scotland from the 5th to 16th centuries.
Say cheese? Victorians said "prunes" instead.
Although the bobcat is rarely seen, it is the most common wildcat in North America.
The Hass avocado was patented in 1935 by Rudolph Hass, a mailman from California.

On April 18, 1930—Good Friday—the BBC reported, “There is no news.”
Instead, they played piano music.
Novelist Patricia Highsmith kept about 300 snails as pets. She carried them in her handbag to parties.
In 1777, Frederick the Great issued an official statement urging his subjects to drink beer in the morning instead of coffee.
In parts of Europe people believe that if you light a cigarette from a candle, a sailor will die.
Ironically, the only member of ZZ Top without a beard has the last name Beard.
The longest case of hiccups lasted 68 years.

The term mortician was invented as part of a PR campaign by the funeral industry, which felt it was more customer-friendly than undertaker. The term was chosen after a call for ideas in Embalmer's Monthly.

December 5 is Krampusnacht (Krampus Night), when the half-goat, half-demon of Christmas folklore visits homes to punish naughty children, armed with a bundle of sticks and a chain to take them back to the underworld.
A newborn giant panda is about the size of a stick of butter.
Asbestos used to be a common sight on film sets. The carcinogenic mineral was a common substitute for snowflakes in filmmaking until shortly after World War II.
The U.S. Senate's Rule XIX, which dates back to 1902, states that a U.S. Senator cannot insult their colleagues.
The American Psychiatric Association’s DSM-5 handbook classifies caffeine withdraws as a mental disorder.
Sphenopalatine ganglioneuralgia is the medical term for brain freeze.
Ronald McDonald is called Donald McDonald in Japan.
Ben Franklin’s formal education ended at 10 years old.
In a 2004 episode of Sesame Street, Cookie Monster revealed that before he started eating cookies his name was Sid.
When you flip a coin, there’s a slightly greater chance that it will end up on the side it started.

When Americans moved out of one house and into another in the early 20th century, they would burn all their old dishcloths so that none of the bad energy that had been wiped up in the old house would move with them into their new abode.
Umchina, a Korean term meaning "mom's friend's son," is used to describe a person who's better at everything than you are.
The word astronaut comes from the Greeks words meaning “star” and “sailor.”
Morton's toe is when your second toe is longer than your big toe. It’s widespread in art, with the Statue of Liberty being one of the more famous examples.
When feeding, a hummingbird can lick 10 to 15 times per second.

In The Empire Strikes Back, an extra can be seen running with what appears to be an ice cream maker. The character became legendary among fans, and was eventually given a name (Willrow Hood) and a backstory.
Sleeping through summer is called estivation.
Blue whales may weigh up to twice as much as the largest dinosaur.
Continental plates drift as fast as fingernails grow.
The MOBA, or the Museum of Bad Art in Somerville, Massachusetts, is pretty much exactly what it sounds like— a collection of really bad art.
Ornithologists often use Cheetos to study behavior in crows. Along with being easy to spot, they’re also one of the birds’ favorite snacks.
Paraskavedekatriaphobia is the fear of Friday the 13th.
The space between your eyebrows is a glabella. That’s also the name of the bone underneath that space that connects your brow ridges.
One of Walt Disney’s first art jobs was drawing cartoons for a local barber in exchange for haircuts.
When a man allegedly found a dead mouse in his can of Mountain Dew, Pepsi had an expert claim in an affidavit that the drink was so acidic it would have dissolved the mouse after 30 days.
Because the speed of Earth’s rotation changes over time, a day in the age of dinosaurs was just 23 hours long.
Nicolas Cage turned down the role of Shrek because he did not want to be an ogre.
Almonds and peaches are members of the same family.
Beaver College changed its name to Arcadia in 2001 in part because anti-porn filters blocked access to the school's website.

It is illegal to flirt in Haddon Township, New Jersey. Under the section “Peace and Good Order,” a person may be punished for approaching “any person of the opposite sex unknown to such person and by word, sign or gesture attempts to speak to or to become acquainted with such person against his will.”
A group of pugs is called a grumble.
Fredric Baur invented the Pringles can. When he passed away in 2008, his ashes were buried in one.
The oldest customer complaint dates back to ancient Mesopotamia. In the nearly 4000-year-old cuneiform tablet, a customer claims he was sold inferior copper ingots.
The Scots have a word for that panicky hesitation you get when you can’t remember someone’s name: tartle.
A solar eclipse helped end a six-year war in 585 BCE. When the sky suddenly darkened during a battle between the Lydians and the Medes in modern Turkey, soldiers took it as a sign to cease fighting.
The record for the longest tire skid was set in 1964 at the Bonneville Salt Flats in Utah.
The FBI called Ted Kaczynski "The Unabomber" because his early mail bombs were sent to universities (UN) and airlines (A).

Born in 1844, Edmonia Lewis became one of the first African American artists to earn international acclaim. She sculpted marble busts of abolitionists like Henry Wadsworth Longfellow and Horace Greeley, and her patrons included President Ulysses S. Grant.
On Good Friday in 1930, the BBC reported, “There is no news.” Instead, they played piano music.
Wyoming is home to only two escalators.
Turkeys (the birds) were named after Turkey (the country.)
Before LeVar Burton signed on, Scott Baio was considered for the hosting role on Reading Rainbow.
It’s a tradition for the post offices of Romeo, Michigan and Juliette, Georgia to offer a special dual postmark leading up to Valentine’s Day.
The ampersand symbol is formed from the letters in et—the Latin word for "and."
Outside North America, Calico Critters are called “Sylvanian Families.”
In 1907, an ad campaign for Kellogg's Corn Flakes offered a free sample of cereal to any woman who would wink at her grocer.
Relative to their body size, barnacles have the biggest penises in the animal kingdom.
In 1953, it took 27 hours to create one PEEPS Marshmallow Chick. The same process takes six minutes today.
Since 1971, Lake Superior State University in Sault Ste. Marie, Michigan has issued permits to unicorn hunters.
On Scooby-Doo, Shaggy’s real name is Norville Rogers.
According to a 2015 study, having 10 more trees on your block can make you feel as healthy as someone who's seven years younger.
All peacocks are male. The females are called “peahens.”
In 1917, the Seattle Metropolitans hockey team became the first American team to win the Stanley Cup.
The Margherita pizza was named after Margherita of Savoy, Queen consort of Italy from 1878 to 1900.
After OutKast sang "Shake it like a Polaroid picture," Polaroid released this statement: "Shaking or waving can actually damage the image"
The AMC Gremlin was released on April 1, 1970. AMC advertised it saying “competitors will find there is nothing ‘April Fool like’ about this car.”
According to the record holder for tallest waffle stack, Guinness World Records has a 40-page document defining what a waffle is.
Grace Jones has a lifetime ban from Disney World.

Dr. Martin Luther King is widely known as one of history’s greatest orators, but that particular skill might not have come so naturally to him. While attending Crozer Theological Seminary, King received a C in public speaking.
At the Gettysburg reunion in 1913, two men purchased a hatchet, walked to the site where their regiments had fought, and buried it.
The most popular Father’s Day gift is a necktie.
A butt is a real unit of measurement for a cask of wine. A buttload is about 108 Imperial gallons.
According to a 2014 study, the melting properties of mozzarella make it the best cheese for topping pizza.
Caribbean sperm whales have their own accents.
In Australia, weed whackers are called whipper snippers.
According to one study, dunking an Oreo in milk for three seconds gives you the optimal balance of sogginess and structural integrity.
The first use of "Google" as a verb in pop culture was on Buffy the Vampire Slayer.
Double Stuf Oreos are only 1.86 times as "stuf’ed" as classic Oreos.
A 150-year-old tree at the Ashikaga Flower Park is believed to be the oldest living wisteria in Japan.
In 2009, a team of scientists searched Scotland’s Loch Ness for evidence of Nessie. They did not find the monster, but they did recover more than 100,000 golf balls.
The term “lawn mullet” means having a neatly manicured front yard and an unmowed mess in the back.
Lake Hillier in Australia is nearly as salty as the Dead Sea. Scientists suspect that some salt-loving bacteria (chiefly Salinibacter ruber) and algae give the lake its pink hue.
The metal bit at the end of a pencil that holds the eraser in place is called a ferrule.
Since founding the Imagination Library in 1995, Dolly Parton has donated 100 million books to children.
Melbourne gave some of its trees email addresses so residents could report problems. Instead, the trees received love letters.
Hippopotomonstrosesquippedaliophobia is the fear of long words.
In his will, William Shakespeare left his wife “my second best bed.”
Benedict Cumberbatch is the second cousin, 16 times removed, of King Richard III—whom he played in the 2016 BBC miniseries The Hollow Crown.
Elton John has pianos named after Aretha Franklin, Nina Simone, and Diana Krall.
In 1953, it took 27 hours to create one PEEPS Marshmallow Chick. Today, that same process takes just six minutes.
The average cumulus cloud weighs roughly 1.1 million pounds.
King Charles III technically owns all the dolphins in UK waters.
After an online vote in 2011, Toyota announced that the official plural of Prius is Prii.
Fern collecting was such a hot fad in the Victorian era that it even had a name: pteridomania.
Nintendo was founded in 1889. Before it sold video games, the Japanese company specialized in playing cards.
Goldfish can distinguish the music of one composer from another.
Before writing Little Women, Louisa May Alcott penned stories under the pseudonyms Flora Fairfield and A.M. Barnard.
“Bloodcurdling” isn’t just an expression: Research shows that watching horror movies can increase a certain clotting protein in our bloodstreams.
Bacon was used to make explosives during World War I (the waste fat was turned into glycerin for the war effort).
Crayola came from the words for “oily chalk.”
Johnny Carson’s first three wives were named, in order, Joan, Joanne, and Joanna. (His first wife went by “Jody.”)

Residents of the Galápagos island of Floreana use a barrel of disorganized mail in place of a formal postal system. Tourists are responsible for sorting through the mail and grabbing any parcels they can deliver on the way to where they’re headed.
The world’s first underwater mailbox was installed just off the shore of Susami, Japan.
30 Rock was known for its fast-paced writing. In 2014, one reporter calculated that there was an average of 7.44 jokes per minute.
In 1872, sitting president Ulysses S. Grant was pulled over and fined $20 for exceeding the Washington speed limit … on a horse.
Stacy “Fergie” Ferguson voiced Sally Brown, Charlie Brown’s kid sister, on several Peanuts cartoons produced in the '80s.
In the late 19th century, Beatrix Potter kept a journal in a secret code so complex it wasn't cracked until 1958.
The aurora australis is the southern version of the aurora borealis. Tasmania, New Zealand, and Antarctica are a few of the best places to scope out the Southern Lights from land.
Referees get Super Bowl rings too.
“Jay” was slang for “foolish person.”  So when a pedestrian ignored street signs, he was a “jaywalker.”
Sorry, Scotland: Persians invented bagpipes.

Wendy’s chocolate Frosty is actually half chocolate and half vanilla because owner Dave Thomas thought an all-chocolate treat would be too overpowering a flavor when paired with their burgers and fries.
When Disneyland was opened in 1955, “Tomorrowland” was designed to look like a year in the distant future: 1986.
The wood frog can hold its pee for up to eight months.
In 1897, Indiana state legislators tried to pass a bill that would have legally redefined the value of pi as 3.2.
A group of clowns is sometimes called a giggle.
The boiling point for water at the top of Mt. Everest is 162°F, about 50 degrees below the boiling point at sea level.

Ira Aldridge was one of the most famous actors of the 19th century. After leaving his home in New York to pursue an acting career in Europe, he performed for royalty, won numerous awards, and used his platform to speak out against slavery.
To ensure the Queen receives her food on time, the clocks in the royal kitchen at Windsor Castle are set five minutes ahead.
There are 293 ways to make change for a U.S. dollar.
Sharks have existed longer than trees.
Viking burials included board games.
Veterans Stadium, former home of the Philadelphia Eagles, featured a courtroom for handling rowdy fans.
One of the world's largest stockpiles of nuclear weapons is located at a U.S. Navy base near Seattle, which is partially defended by trained dolphins.
If you have a daily routine, some scientists believe that dogs can tell when you’re coming home by how much of your scent is left in the house.
Two grandsons of President John Tyler—the 10th president of the United States, who was born in 1790—are still alive.
Johnny Cash's "A Boy Named Sue" was penned by beloved children's author Shel Silverstein.

Early 20th-century Pennsylvania Germans considered it bad luck to take a bath or change your clothing between Christmas and the New Year (and if you change your underwear between the holidays, "you will be full of boils").
A baby puffin is called a puffling, and both parents take turns incubating the egg before it hatches.
When Steven Spielberg re-enrolled at California State, Long Beach to earn his BA more than 30 years after dropping out, he was given three course credits in paleontology for making Jurassic Park.
The word PEZ comes from the German word for peppermint—PfeffErminZ.
The national animal of Scotland is the unicorn.

Astronauts on Mars won’t just make plans based on temperature—they’ll also need to consider tau, the level of particulate matter in the atmosphere. High tau levels will block sunlight to solar-powered rovers.
The corpse flower was the official flower of the Bronx for 60 years.
According to a 2015 study, sarcasm can promote creative thinking.
Baby porcupines are known as porcupettes.
The Woolsey Hall auditorium at Yale contains an extra-wide seat built to fit alumnus and former professor William Howard Taft
Half of the world's geothermal features, and two-thirds of all the world's geysers, are found in Yellowstone National Park.
A 2013 study suggests that chewing gum boosts concentration.
Scottish band The Bay City Rollers chose their name after sticking a pin in a map of America, which landed on the Michigan city.
During World War II, the term security blanket was slang for measures meant to keep military information secret, or covered up.
Elvis Presley’s manager sold “I Hate Elvis” badges as a way to make money off of people who weren’t buying his merchandise.

A team of chemists described old book smell as “a combination of grassy notes with a tang of acids and a hint of vanilla over an underlying mustiness.” The odor actually comes from chemicals like benzaldehyde, furfural, and acetic acid—all byproducts of decomposition.
"Huh?" is understood in all languages.
In 1965, Tommy Cash—Johnny Cash's younger brother—released a song titled "I Didn't Walk the Line."
After passing a kidney stone, in 2006 William Shatner sold it for $25,000 to an online casino. The casino wanted the ensuing publicity; Shatner donated the money to Habitat for Humanity.
Queen Elizabeth II had over 30 corgis in her lifetime.

Benjamin Franklin never lobbied for the turkey to become the national bird, but he did write that the bald eagle was a fowl of “bad moral character” and that the turkey was “a much more respectable Bird.”
Trained pigeons can differentiate between the paintings of Pablo Picasso and Claude Monet.
In her will, author Dorothy Parker left her estate to Martin Luther King Jr. and the NAACP following his death. The organization still owns the rights to her work today.
Harriet Tubman was the first woman to lead a U.S. military raid.
Belly button lint is caused by hairs on the abdomen funneling fibers into the belly button.
Ernest Hemingway once checked out F. Scott Fitzgerald's penis in the men's room to assure him it was a normal size.
There's a five-story, blood-red waterfall in Antarctica.
National Donut Day originally started as a way to honor Salvation Army volunteers who served donuts to soldiers in WWI.
A butt is a real unit of measurement for a cask of wine. A buttload is about 108 Imperial gallons.
Jurassic Park author Michael Crichton was taller than Michael Jordan.
There's a basketball court above the Supreme Court. It's known as the Highest Court in the Land.
Staff members of the Slovak and Slovenian embassies meet once a month to exchange incorrectly addressed mail.
The second-half kickoff in Super Bowl I had to be done twice, as NBC didn’t cut back from commercial in time to catch the first one on camera.
Paraskavedekatriaphobia is the fear of Friday the 13th.
At the Wife Carrying World Championships in Finland, first prize is the wife's weight in beer.
During World War II, the United States began rationing shoes. Citizens were allowed three.
Sweden is so efficient, only one percent of its garbage ends up in a landfill.
Madam C.J. Walker is thought to be America’s first self-made female millionaire. Born to sharecroppers in 1867, she made her fortune selling beauty products for black women.
The second largest country by area is Canada, after Russia.
Duncan Hines was a real person. He was a popular restaurant critic who also wrote a book of hotel recommendations.
Before he was the best-selling author of The Da Vinci Code, Dan Brown tried his luck as a musician. In 1994 he released an album called Angels & Demons—a title he reused for a 2000 novel.
Despite producing 95 percent of the world’s bourbon supply, the official drink of Kentucky is milk.
Continental plates drift as fast as fingernails grow.
By total area, Canada is the world’s second largest country. Only Russia is larger.
Female cicadas have been known to confuse the roar of power tools for mating calls, sometimes swarming people using lawn mowers.
Apollo 17 astronaut Harrison Schmitt was allergic to moon dust.
Ciabatta bread was only invented in 1982.
In colonial America, lobster wasn’t exactly a delicacy. In fact, it was so cheap and plentiful that it was often served to prisoners.
The Karni Mata Temple in Deshnoke, India, is home to 20,000 rats who are believed to be descended from an incarnation of the Hindu goddess Durga.
An episode of Peppa Pig was pulled from Australian television for teaching children not to fear spiders.
Sea cucumbers eat with their feet.
Humans are the only animals that blush.
If you adjust for inflation, Gone With the Wind is the highest-grossing movie of all time, earning approximately $1.8 billion.

Some libraries went to extraordinary lengths to make sure their titles remained on shelves. At Marsh’s Library in Dublin, Ireland, visitors hoping to peruse rare books in the 1800s were locked in cages until they were done reading.
Sloths may be the only mammals that don’t fart.
Rather than store it, parade officials released a gigantic dachshund balloon into the air at the conclusion of the 1929 Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade.
The swirling blue shades of the Marble Caves in Chile are a reflection of the turquoise lake waters below them. The hues change subtly as sea levels fall and rise.
Forrest Mars, the creator of Peanut M&M's, was allergic to peanuts.
Dolphin calves are typically born tail first, rather than head first, so they don’t drown during the birthing process.

Without Earth’s protective magnetic field, astronauts on Mars will be exposed to solar radiation that may affect their mental fitness. They could experience lapses in attention and slower reaction times.
Scientists have found evidence of take-out restaurants in the remains of Pompeii.
In 1974, the Journal of Applied Behavior Analysis published a paper titled "The Unsuccessful Self-Treatment of a Case of 'Writer’s Block.'" It contained a total of zero words.
Wendy's founder Dave Thomas dropped out of high school but picked up his GED in 1993. His GED class voted him Most Likely to Succeed.
According to a 2010 study, people fluent in multiple languages almost always swear in their native tongue.
Hollywood starlet Hedy Lamarr is often called the “mother of Wi-Fi.” She helped invent a version of the frequency-hopping system that led to the creation of GPS, Bluetooth, and wireless internet.
It took the editors of the first Oxford English Dictionary five years to reach the word ant.
A study done by the University of Glasgow found that dogs appear to prefer reggae and soft rock over other genres of music.
A “contronym” is a word that’s its own opposite. For example: if you seed the lawn you add seeds, but if you seed a tomato you remove them.
High schools and universities in New Zealand are allowed to keep up to a pound of uranium on the premises for educational purposes.
Bela Lugosi was buried in full Dracula costume—cape and all.
At one point in the 1990s it was estimated that 50 percent of all CDs produced worldwide were for AOL.
Stalin plotted to kill John Wayne.

Stuck inside on a rainy day in 1816, writers Mary Shelley, Percy Shelley, Lord Byron, and John Polidori challenged each other to a scary story writing contest. Mary came up with the idea for Frankenstein and published it two years later at age 20.
Galileo's middle finger is on display at the Museo Galileo in Florence, Italy.
“Q” is the only letter of the alphabet that does not appear in any U.S. territory or state name.

According to legend, and the official story from Nathan's, four immigrants held the first hot dog eating contest at Nathan's Famous stand on Coney Island on July 4, 1916 to prove who was the most patriotic.

Unconsciously, native English speakers say adjectives preceding nouns in a specific order: opinion, size, age, shape, color, origin, material, and purpose. It's why saying "old green metal chairs" sounds normal, but "metal green old chairs" sounds weird.
The original version of Monopoly was a cautionary tale against the perils of capitalism.
Venetia Burney, who at age 11 suggested the name “Pluto” for the ninth planet in our solar system, lived to see it demoted to a dwarf planet in 2006.

Roald Dahl passed away on November 23, 1990 at the age of 74. Per his request, he was buried with all of his favorite things: snooker cues, a bottle of Burgundy, chocolate, HB pencils, and a power saw.
The average American typically eats between 3000 and 5000 calories at Thanksgiving dinner.
Toni Morrison edited Muhammad Ali’s 1975 autobiography ‘The Greatest: My Own Story.’
Novelist Patricia Highsmith kept approximately 300 snails as pets and would regularly carry as many as 100 of them in her handbag to parties.
A litter of kittens is also known as a “kindle.”
The Mayflower landed at Plymouth Rock in 1620. A journal from the ship reads, “We could not now take time for further search or consideration; our victuals being much spent especially our Beere.”
The Truman Show Delusion is a mental condition marked by a patient’s belief that they are the star of an imaginary reality show.
The 1967 Outer Space Treaty forbids any nation from trying to own the Moon.
Shirley Temple reportedly didn't love her famous curls; she preferred the cropped hairstyle of her hero Amelia Earhart.
Before earning a living as a writer, Octavia E. Butler once worked as a potato chip inspector.
Flamingos aren’t naturally pink; they’re born a sort of grayish color. It’s their diet of brine shrimp and algae that turns them pink.
According to one study, most dogs reach peak cuteness between six and eight weeks old.
Bedding was such a luxury in the Middle Ages that blankets and sheets were written into wills.
The plural of cul-de-sac is culs-de-sac.
Marie Curie’s notebooks are still radioactive.
Mr. Rogers always mentioned out loud that he was feeding his fish because a young blind viewer once asked him to do so. She wanted to know the fish were OK.
John Quincy Adams was an avid skinny-dipper. His regular exercise regimen included dips in the Potomac River.
The human body emits visible light, but it's not visible to the naked eye.
Plants have ways of communicating with each other. The scent of freshly cut grass is equivalent to a cry for help.
When swallowed by toads, bombardier beetles project hot, noxious chemicals from their anuses, which sometimes forces the predators to puke them back up.
President Jefferson hated formal affairs so much that he would often greet foreign dignitaries while wearing pajamas.
Sleeping through summer is called estivation.
There's a library in Ankara, Turkey, that's filled with discarded books trash collectors rescued from landfills.
Ray Bradbury wrote the first draft of Fahrenheit 451 on a rented typewriter in the basement of the UCLA library in just nine days.
In Colombia, dried ants replace popcorn as the typical movie theater snack.
Thomas Edison nicknamed two of his kids (Dot and Dash) after the Morse code signals.
According to NASA, it possibly rains glass on the planet known as HD 189733b.
Movie trailers are called that for a reason: They used to run after the movie.
Over half the world's population lives within a 5000-mile-wide circle in East Asia.
Steve Carell worked as a postal carrier in the small town of Littleton, Massachusetts. (Though he only did it for a few months, he said it was the hardest job he's ever had.)
Female bats give birth while hanging upside down, catching the baby in their wings as it drops.
Humans beings are the only animals confirmed to cry tears in response to emotions.
Coyotes outpace roadrunners by 23 mph.
The annual number of worldwide shark bites is 10 times less than the number of people bitten by other people in New York.
According to a 2017 survey, "whatever" tops the list of words Americans find most annoying for the ninth year in a row.
There are beaches in the Maldives that glow in the dark.
The “Jolene” character in Dolly Parton’s hit song is based on a real person: a bank teller who would flirt mercilessly with Dolly’s husband.
Amerigo Vespucci, for whom many historians believe America was named, was an Italian merchant.
In 1939, Hitler's nephew wrote an article called "Why I Hate My Uncle." He came to the U.S., served in the Navy, and settled on Long Island.
Over the course of her sixty-three-year reign, Queen Victoria survived eight assassination attempts.

Walt Disney World is a surprisingly popular place for people to scatter their loved one's ashes. Disney, understandably, takes a strong stand against the practice, saying that anyone who brings human remains onto the property will be kicked out.
Wax-modeling pioneer Madame Tussaud was nearly executed by guillotine during the French Revolution.
Bones found at Seymour Island indicate that, 37 to 40 million years ago, penguins stood at a formidable 6 feet tall and weighed 250 pounds.
The shark on the Jaws and the T.Rex on the Jurassic Park poster were both modeled after exhibits at the American Museum of Natural History.
At one time, George Washington was the nation's largest whiskey producer. He made 11,000 gallons in 1799.
Mexico’s full name translates to "The United States of Mexico."
The Starry Night depicts Vincent Van Gogh's view from the Saint Paul-de-Mausole asylum.
There was a third Apple founder. Ronald Wayne sold his 10 percent stake for $800 in 1976.
The 100 folds in a chef’s toque are said to represent 100 ways to cook an egg.
There are 293 ways to make change for a US dollar.
Viking men wore makeup.
The FBI investigated the song “Louie Louie” because people thought the lyrics were dirty. After three months, the FBI abandoned the investigation because it couldn’t make out the words.

Future Martians might marvel at the Valles Marineris (a.k.a. Mariner Valley) the same way Earthlings marvel at the Grand Canyon. The huge rift is more than eight times the length of the Grand Canyon, and four times as deep.
George Washington was among America's largest whiskey producers.
While death by guillotine might seem like an ancient ritual, the practice was still in use in France up until 1977—when the original Star Wars was in theaters.

Cathay Williams became the first African-American woman to serve in the U.S. army in 1866. Since women were barred from joining the military at the time, she enlisted as a man under the pseudonym William Cathay.
The original title for Scream was Scary Movie.
The cubicle did not get its name from its shape, but from the Latin “cubiculum” meaning bed chamber.

Australia is home to approximately 170 kinds of snakes, including some of the world’s most venomous. The good news? Snake bites aren’t common and are rarely fatal. One study estimated that snake bites account for just two deaths per year in Australia.
The sum of all the numbers on a roulette wheel is 666.
There really was a Captain Morgan. He was a Welsh pirate who later became the lieutenant governor of Jamaica.
Just 3 percent of bird species have penises.
The only Blockbuster store in the world that is still operating is located in Bend, Oregon.
During WWII, La-Z-Boy manufactured seats for tanks, torpedo boats, gun turrets, and armored cars.
A 21-year-old man from Arizona saved a woman's life using CPR he learned watching an episode of The Office.
In 1997, a woman from Louisville left actor Charles Bronson all of her money in a handwritten will—a total of about $300,000.  She'd never met him; she was just a fan.
Family Feud host Richard Dawson met his second wife, Gretchen Johnson, when she was a contestant on the show in 1981. And yes, he kissed her.
The feral puppies in Chernobyl are radioactive.
Golf legend Jack Nicklaus earned his nickname, the Golden Bear, thanks to his size and blond hair. Conveniently, it was also the name of his high school mascot.

Alice in Wonderland was once banned in parts of China. “Bears, lions, and other beasts cannot use human language,” said the Governor of the Hunan Province in 1931. “To attribute to them such a power is an insult to the human race.”
In her will, author Dorothy Parker left her estate to Martin Luther King Jr. and the NAACP following his death. The organization still owns the rights to her work today.
Both John Adams and Thomas Jefferson died on July 4, 1826, exactly 50 years after the adoption of the Declaration of Independence.
The word "dude" originated in the 1800s as an insult to men overly concerned with the latest fashion trends.

Killdeer birds fake injuries to fool predators. The species will feign being injured in order to lure predators toward them and away from their nest of offspring. When the predator gets close enough, the killdeer miraculously “recovers” and beats a hasty retreat.
Japan is home to about a dozen "cat islands"—places where cats significantly outnumber people.
The BBC played David Bowie’s “Space Oddity” during its moon landing coverage in 1969.
In 1947, The New York Times noted that “The pizza could be as popular a snack as the hamburger if Americans only knew more about it.”
The Eiffel Tower leans slightly toward the shade on sunny days.
Green eyes are extremely rare: only 2 percent of the population has them, and they’re more common in females than males.
The medical term for ice cream headaches is sphenopalatine ganglioneuralgia.
The national animal of Scotland is the unicorn.
President Theodore Roosevelt, who died 25 days before Robinson was born, was the inspiration for Jackie Robinson’s middle name.
“Horizontal refreshment” was a 19th century slang term for sex.
The first item sold on eBay was a broken laser pointer.

In the early 20th century, the area now known as Glass Beach in California was used as a trash dump. Decades of ocean tides have cleared the beach and polished the discarded bottles and automobile tail lights into colorful pebbles of sea glass.

In 1985, the Chicago Bears recorded a hit rap song called “The Super Bowl Shuffle,” which was nominated for a Grammy award for Best Rhythm and Blues Performance by a Duo or Group With Vocal. Ultimately, they lost to Prince’s “Kiss."
We invented booze before we invented the wheel.
The Library of Congress pays to reproduce popular magazines in Braille.
Before he was the best-selling author of The Da Vinci Code, Dan Brown tried his luck as a musician. In 1994, he released an album called Angels & Demons, a title he reused for a 2000 novel.
Nineteenth-century British surgeon George Merryweather believed leeches could predict the weather. His "tempest prognosticator," displayed at the Great Exhibition in 1851, failed to catch on.
The Mobile Phone Throwing World Championships are held in Finland.  A recent winner said he prepared for the event by “mainly drinking.”
Pentheraphobia is the intense and disproportionate fear of your mother-in-law.
The average cumulus cloud weighs roughly 1.1 million pounds.
The Czech name for the movie ‘Bad Santa’ roughly translates to ‘Santa is a Pervert.’
Chinese checkers was invented in Germany.
IKEA consumes about 1 percent of the world's lumber.
In 1985, Aretha Franklin's voice was declared a "natural resource" of the state of Michigan.
The three dots on the Domino's logo represent the chain's three original locations. Co-founder Tom Monaghan originally planned to add a new dot for every pizzeria he opened.
In Queensland, Australia, it's illegal to own a pet rabbit unless you're a magician.
In 1998, a Georgia student was suspended for wearing a Pepsi shirt to "Coke in Education Day."
France is the most visited country in the world.
Foreign Accent Syndrome is a rare side effect of brain trauma. Patients speak their native language in a foreign dialect.
There's a basketball court above the Supreme Court. It's known as the Highest Court in the Land.
Marie Curie remains the only person to earn Nobel prizes in two different sciences.
Weird Al Yankovic wrote his parody song “The Saga Begins” before Star Wars: Episode I was released. LucasFilm denied his request to see it early, so he relied on internet spoilers for plot details.
Scotland’s national anthem is the unicorn.
The verb "unfriend" appeared in 1659.
Maine is the U.S. state closest to Africa.
There's only one Blockbuster still operating in the U.S.—it's located in Bend, Oregon.
According to the Oxford English Dictionary, publicly is the most commonly misspelled word in the English language.
Danny DeVito is an experienced hairdresser.
An urban legend claimed Zima was not detectable by a breathalyzer, boosting its popularity among the young and gullible.
Green Eggs and Ham was banned in China from 1965 to 1991 for its “portrayal of early Marxism.”
Bloodcurdling isn’t just an expression. Research shows that watching horror movies can increase a certain clotting protein in our blood.
Bacon was used to make explosives during World War II.
The first Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade featured lions, camels, and elephants from the Central Park Zoo.
Redondo Beach, California adopted the Goodyear Blimp as the city's official bird in 1983.
A solar eclipse helped end a six-year war in 585 BCE. When the sky suddenly darkened during a battle between the Lydians and the Medes in modern Turkey, soldiers took it as a sign to cease fighting.
As comedian Bob Hope lay on his deathbed in 2003, his wife Dolores asked where he’d like to be buried. His reply: “Surprise me.”
The modern popped collar originated as a way to keep tennis players’ necks from getting sunburnt.
The Kjeragbolten boulder on Norway's Kjerag mountain was left in a crevasse during the last ice age. It's now a popular spot for BASE jumpers.
When Hattie McDaniel became the first African American to win an Oscar in 1940, she had to make her way to the stage from a segregated table at the back of the room.
Eighteen percent of Americans claim to have seen or felt the presence of a ghost.
The plot of ‘The Nightmare Before Christmas’ was partly inspired by the collision of holiday store decorations.
The paint that coats the White House and Buckingham Palace is made by the same German company.
At the Poison Garden of Alnwick Castle in England, many of the plants are so deadly they're grown in cages.
Before he became president, Abraham Lincoln was wrestling champion of his county in Illinois. He fought in nearly 300 matches and lost only one.
The position dogs assume when they're inviting other pets to play is called a play bow.
Kea parrots spread warbles when they’re in a good mood, making them the first known non-mammal species to communicate with infectious laughter.
If your dog's feet smell like corn chips, you're not alone. The term "Frito Feet" was coined to describe the scent.
Quetzalcoatlus, the largest known flying animal ever, was as tall as a giraffe. It may have used its powerful forelimbs to pole-vault into the sky.
A cough can propel saliva droplets as far as 20 feet at speeds up to 25 to 50 mph.
Honey hunters in Mozambique use special calls to recruit the services of birds known as honeyguides. The birds lead the humans to bees' nests and in return, they get the leftover beeswax.
Boring, Oregon and Dull, Scotland have been sister cities since 2012. In 2017, they added Bland Shire, Australia to their “League of Extraordinary Communities.”
While an Oscar is of unnamed value to someone who wins (or loses) one, the actual trophy has a raw value of about $600.
There's a segment of the Berlin wall in the men's bathroom of a Las Vegas casino.
In 1907, an ad campaign for Kellogg’s Corn Flakes offered a free sample of cereal to any customer who would wink at their grocer.
When Angelfire launched in the mid-1990s, it offered medical transcription services as well as web-building tools.
When asked if Abe had any hobbies, Mary Todd Lincoln said, “Cats.”
Sleep literally cleans your brain. During slumber, more cerebrospinal fluid flushes through the brain to wash away harmful proteins and toxins that build up during the day.
In late May or early June of each year, the synchronous fireflies of the Great Smoky Mountains flash in sync. The light show is made up of males blinking for the females on the forest floor below.
Alexander Graham Bell, who invented the telephone in 1876, suggested answering calls with "ahoy."
Night of the Living Dead director George A. Romero got his start making short films for Mister Rogers’ Neighborhood.
Mike Tyson would KO sparring partners quickly so he could get home in time to watch ‘Tom & Jerry.’
Mars’s dust storms, the planet’s defining weather feature, are the largest in the solar system and can last for months.
Newborn babies have nearly 100 more bones than full-grown adults.
St. Patrick wasn't Irish: He was born to Roman parents in either Scotland, England, or Wales.
Alaska is simultaneously the westernmost and easternmost state.

In 897, Pope Stephen VI had the corpse of a previous pope, Formosus, exhumed, perched on a throne, and questioned about his "crimes" (which was largely motivated by a political struggle.) The event is known as the Cadaver Synod.
The Statue of Liberty wears a size 879 shoe.
People didn’t always say “hello” when they answered the phone. When the first regular phone service was established in 1878, Alexander Graham Bell suggested answering the phone with “ahoy."
Ackwards is an old English dialect word that describes a creature lying on its back that can't get up.
Born in the USA was the first commercial CD made in America.
Beethoven went out of his way to ensure his morning coffee was made with exactly 60 beans per cup.
Yoda was partly modeled after a photo of Albert Einstein.
The number 4 is the only number with the same number of letters as the meaning of its name.
The first pair of Nike running shoes was made in a waffle iron.
On average, people in India spend 10 hours and 42 minutes a week reading, the most time of any country on Earth.
Murmurations are the graceful, undulating patterns starlings create when they flock together in the sky. Scientists are still unsure how the birds coordinate their movements so quickly.
During Ronald Reagan’s presidency, Air Force One was outfitted with jellybean holders to keep the president’s favorite snack from spilling.
Editor Bennett Cerf challenged Dr. Seuss to write a book using no more than 50 different words. The result? Green Eggs and Ham.
The verb "unfriend" first appeared in 1659.
The Mall of America has its own ZIP code. (It’s 55425.)
Beauty and the Beast was the first animated film to be nominated for Best Picture. It lost to The Silence of the Lambs.
Spiders recycle webs by eating them.
Charles Richter, of the Richter scale was an avid nudist.

The Hardy Tree in London’s St. Pancras churchyard is named for Thomas Hardy. The Victorian writer worked at the burial ground in the 1860s and rearranged tombstones around the base of an ash tree to make room for a railway expansion.
Fish cough.

Back in the 1800s, composer Franz Liszt was worshiped like a rock star. In fact, he received so many requests for locks of his hair that he eventually bought a dog, only to snip off patches of its fur to send to his admirers.
When Texas was its own sovereign nation in the mid-1800s, it briefly had a diplomatic mission in Paris.
Volvo gave away the 1962 patent for their revolutionary three-point seat belt for free, in order to save lives.
Amelia Earhart and Eleanor Roosevelt once sneaked out of a White House event, commandeered an airplane, and went on a joyride to Baltimore.

Regular fluctuations in Mars’s atmospheric pressure, temperature, and wind produce snowstorms with surprising predictability. Long-term weather forecasts could allow astronauts to avoid travel where a storm will happen.
The al-Qarawiyyin Library in Fez, Morocco is the oldest working library in the world.
A black cat crossing your path (from right to left) is considered good luck in Germany.
Many people are either right- or left-eared and eyed in the same way we're right- or left-handed.
In curling, good sportsmanship and politeness are essential. Congratulating opponents on plays and abstaining from trash talk are part of what’s known as the “Spirit of Curling.”
Astronauts can grow up to 3 percent taller in space than they are on Earth because of the weightlessness causes the spine to expand.
Fredrick Douglass was deemed the 19th century’s most photographed American.
In 1964 a pre-fame David Bowie was interviewed on the BBC program Tonight at age 17 as the founder of The Society For The Prevention of Cruelty to Long-Haired Men.
People used to believe that the blood of the freshly executed was a health tonic and would pay executioners a little money to let them drink it warm.
A stork shot by a hunter in Germany in 1822 was found with a Central African spear piercing its throat, providing scientists with the first evidence for long-distance bird migration.
In Italy, it’s considered bad luck to lay bread upside down—either on a table or in a basket.
When it comes to wine, annd Sauvignon Blanc in particular, a cat pee-like aroma is often indicative of a high-quality vintage.
Chock Full o' Nuts coffee does not contain nuts. It's named for a chain of nut stores that the founder converted into coffee shops.
Despite the optical illusion, the Gateway Arch is exactly as wide (630 feet) as it is tall.
Before the internet, Nintendo employed “game counselors” whom players could call for advice and assistance navigating a game.
Winston Churchill's mother was born in Brooklyn.
The raven that inspired Edgar Allan Poe's poem was named Grip, and he was Charles Dickens’s beloved pet.
Martin Van Buren wrote an autobiography without mentioning his wide.
